awd_titl_txt: EAPSI:Analyzing the Interaction of Written-Language Complexity and Speech Duration to Understand the Effects of Literacy on Spoken Language
awd_abstract_narration:
Previous research has found a link in English between how a sound is spelled and the duration of that sound. For tic, click, and clique, the final /k/ sound is longer in click versus tic, and longer still in clique. It has yet to be determined if children acquire these patterns naturally from adults' speech or if this develops through the process of becoming literate. This question is difficult to test in English: words that sound similar but vary only in the spelling of specific sounds are not widely known to preliterate children. However, this effect may be influenced by written-language complexity relative to a language's writing system rather than just by alphabetic letters. Thus, this effect could be present in languages without alphabets. Japanese has a character-based writing system. It also has a larger number of words that have similar pronunciations known to preliterate children but are written differently with varying levels of complexity. Working with Dr. Montserrat Sanz of Kobe City University of Foreign Studies in Japan, the PI will collect speech data from Japanese speakers to determine if durational differences linked to written-language complexity are also present in languages other than English. If this is the case, speech patterns from preliterate Japanese children and literate adults can be compared to determine if this effect is influenced by literacy. This research can lead to the development of low-cost, non-invasive technologies that use speech data to detect reading or developmental disorders in children.

Research has found a correlation between orthography and speech duration in English: the duration of a word-final consonant is a function of the number of letters used in its orthographic representation. This effect has not been studied outside of English but may be influenced by orthographic complexity relative to a language's orthography rather than just phonologically-salient letters. If this is the case, a similar effect should be present in languages with orthographies other than alphabets. The PI will collect speech data from Japanese speakers and analyze speech duration as a function of orthographic complexity of kanji. If Japanese exhibits similar durational patterns, speech data from Japanese children of various stages of literacy (including preliterate) and literate adults will be compared to determine whether these durational effects are acquired naturally or develop through literacy. This research can lead to techniques to test for reading and developmental disorders in children through analyses of their speech

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

por.por_cntn:
Shannon Grippando conducted research on the effects of written-language complexity in Japanese speakers’ speech patterns with Dr. Montserrat Sanz of Kobe City University of Foreign Studies, Japan.

Previous research found that the spelling length of English sounds affects the speech duration of those sounds. For instance, the final /k/ in clique was found to be slightly but significantly longer in duration than the final /k/ in click. This effect is independent of word frequency and the frequency of a sound’s spelling convention.

Prior to this project, it was not yet known if this effect was limited to languages with alphabets which have discrete, phonologically-salient letters. We hypothesized that similar durational effects would be present cross-linguistically in languages with other types of writing systems if this effect is not solely dependent on letters. Under this view, each writing system would have a basic unit of written-language complexity. A higher written-complexity value would influence a longer speech duration in a word, all else being equal. So speakers of a language with a character-based writing system, like Japanese, could potentially display similar durational speech patterns as those found in English, though these effects would be correlated with a measure of written-language complexity distinct to the Japanese writing system.

We investigated two possible measures of written-language complexity in Japanese: 1) the number of pen strokes in a single character; or 2) the number of whole characters in a single word (see Figure 1 for examples). Native Japanese speakers from Kobe City University of Foreign Studies were shown words consisting of heterographic homophone pairs (words that sound alike but are written differently) and read the words aloud. Each pair of homophones contained a word with high written-language complexity (more pen strokes or more characters) and a word with low written-language complexity (fewer pen strokes or fewer characters). Participants' speech was recorded, and speech duration was measured and compared using speech analysis software.

The results of our experiments showed that the number of characters in a word had a significant effect on speech duration, but the number of pen strokes in a single character did not. Stimuli in the character condition consisted of words with three phones and words with four phones. Additional analyses showed that the number of whole characters in a word only had a significant effect on speech duration in four-phone words. Four-phone, two-character words were on average 20 milliseconds longer than four-phone, one-character words.

Further research is required to explain why this effect is present only in four-phone words. Four-phone words in this experiment contained two consonants, while three-phone words contained only one consonant. Previous research found durational effects correlated with spelling length in English consonants, but the effect of spelling length on vowel duration has not yet been investigated. Durational effects from written-language complexity may have lesser or no effect on vowel length, especially in a language like Japanese where vowel length can be the distinguishing feature between two separate words (e.g. /toru/ "to take" versus /tooru/ "to go through"). Consonant length can also distinguish words in Japanese, but this occurs in more restricted phonetic environments than vowel length distinctions. Future analyses will be conducted at the sound level to determine the nature of this effect.

To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of speech lengthening effects correlated with the number of characters in a word's written representation. We interpret our results as evidence in support of whole characters being a basic unit of written-language complexity in Japanese which can influence speech duration. Finding such an effect in Japanese opens the door to further studies to determine the locus and nature of durational speech effects correlated with written-language. In the future we will compare the speech patterns of Japanese-speaking adults to preliterate children's to determine to what extent durational effects are driven by the development of literacy. This was previously difficult to accomplish in English due to English's lack of ideal stimuli of concrete, homophonic words known to children. Such pairs of words are more prevalent in Japanese. We have begun to collaborate with a local board of education in Japan to collect speech data from young children.

Our continued analyses of this data and our future research directions will help us better understand minute differences in speech patterns and how the development of literacy impacts speech. This knowledge could be applied to improving the accuracy of speech recognition software, and we have begun to explore ways in which this can be implemented. Future research will also focus on whether the absence of speech patterns correlated with written-language complexity can be used as a means to help detect and possibly diagnosis reading and learning disabilities in children.
